answers.answer: Damn!! That's way too high period. My doctor is confused about my Blood sugar lvls... one day they are fine the next over 200. I'm actually surprised you haven't gained more than 24lbs. I have to check my sugar 4 or more times a day. That's not really that bad.... just a finger *****.  They even admitted into the hospital me last wk to get my sugar lvls under control. I don't know how much GD and preeclamsia are going to effect each other, but I don't think it will make it worse. I also don't think you will be put on bed rest.  I do however think your doctor will probably want you delivered around 35wks if you can make it that long. GD if not under control becomes dangerous for you and the baby. My doctor doesn't like to see anything over 200 EVER. You should change the way you eat. It helps tremendously..... usually. Cut out carbs and sugar as much as possible. Drink lots and lots and lots and lots of water. The way the doctors explained it to me when your Sugar gets too high and bounces too much it can make your little ones sick too. I'm not trying to scare you. But it is a very serious thing. You can message me on myspace if you want to talk more :)

Chellybeans,Watch out what veggies you are eating--some are very high in carbs--also milk is high on the carb list.  I know when I had GD I needed to limit milk--to like an 8 oz glass total...also green beans are my favorite and those I could only have like 1/2 c--fruits are high in carbs also---Pasta is bad for the diabetes  try and stick with meats, eggs, proteins..and then a small serving of the fruits and veggies..your doctor should also have you meet with a dietician..she will have wonderful pamphlets on serving sizes to help control the sugar.  good luck with the babies.

Chelly,Nothing you did, nor is your water treatment to blame for this or your pre-eclampsia (though sometimes the sodium in water softners is not the best for people with severe hypertension.You are at more risk for both GD and preeclampsia due to the twin gestation.  The GD won't lead to bedrest, but simply being pregnant with twins may, at some point.  Also, if your BP is out of control, often you are put on some rest for that.You'll be given lots of education about your GD, and hopefully a dietician will work with you.  Be strict about following a diet, it makes a big difference in the end.  You'll probably end up with 3 meals and 2 snacks a day, and all have to be timed appropriately for the insulin to do its job right.

thanks so much. you got to the heart of whats been eating at me. i have been really worried i did this. my doctor has a nurse liason(not sure what her role is) that is supposed to see me this afternoon to educate me on the glucometer(it records my blood levels so the doctor can read them weekly) and how exactly to inject myself. they called in my prescriptions and have a dietician in the works for me too.my blood pressure is not too out of control. i have managed to pretty much stabilize it at a high level. it's been running 150's over 90's to 106ish. i have been on inderal for it and that seems to keep it from spiking, although yesterday did not help and i had a spike where i saw spots and got dizzy.if i don't eat as often as 3 meals and 2 snacks will they increase it?my typical day i eat a piece of fruit for breakfast with a glass of milk. sometimes i skip this mealthen at lunch i have a sandwich(pb&j or tuna or egg salad usually) with animal crackers or ritz bits or something similar, a cup of pineapple or grapes and water,then i eat dinner meat veggie and small starch(rice or pasta ocassionally potatoes). usually only finish the meat and most of the veggie some of my starch.sometimes i have a small snack before bed. not often.i don't eat as much as recommended because i always feel full, absolutely not because i am trying to watch my weight. just for the record.

They'll probably have you increase your lean proteins somewhat.  And probably will have you strictly regulating your fruits...you won't have to cut them completely, but they may be cut somewhat.  There may be other changes, but you'll learn to do it.Even if you don't feel hungry though, its important to eat EXACTLY what they tell you to, b/c that will affect how much insulin you need.  If they prescribe a certain amount of insulin, and you wind up not eating much that day, you might have low blood sugar.  Or if you over eat or eat the wrong things, you might be higher all the time.Sometimes women are hospitalized for glucose control initially, if their sugars are way out of whack while starting insulin.  Hopefully that won't happen.  If it does, its often for just a few days.  The important thing is to do and follow the diet exactly.

Get a notebook, too.  You'll be writing everything down.  Everything.  They'll probably give you a log of some type, but it usually doesn't have enough room to write everything down.  You'll be writing what you eat, what your blood sugars are, and how much insulin you took, and when.
